verses.text: The children of Israel again did what was evil in the LORD’s sight after Ehud died.
verses.comment: The Hebrew literally says 'the sons of Israel,' but 'children of Israel' is the common traditional rendering.

verses.text: So the LORD sold them into the hand of Jabin, king of Canaan, who reigned in Hazor. The commander of his army was Sisera, who lived in Harosheth-haggoyim.
verses.comment: 'Sold them' is a literal translation indicating God gave Israel over to their enemies.

verses.text: Then the children of Israel cried out to the LORD, for Jabin had nine hundred iron chariots, and he oppressed the children of Israel harshly for twenty years.
verses.comment: The adjective 'harshly' captures the sense of 'with violence' or 'cruelly.'

verses.text: Now Deborah, a prophetess, the wife of Lappidoth, was judging Israel at that time.
verses.comment: 'Prophetess' translates the Hebrew word for a female prophet.

verses.text: She used to sit under the palm of Deborah between Ramah and Bethel in the hill country of Ephraim, and the children of Israel came up to her for judgment.
verses.comment: Maintained the common rendering 'sat under the palm' and clarified locations.

verses.text: She sent and called for Barak the son of Abinoam from Kedesh in Naphtali, and said to him, 'Has not the LORD, the God of Israel, commanded you, “Go, gather your men at Mount Tabor, taking ten thousand men from the people of Naphtali and the people of Zebulun”?'
verses.comment: 'Has not the LORD commanded' reflects the emphatic Hebrew question.

verses.text: 'And I will draw out Sisera, the commander of Jabin’s army, with his chariots and his multitude, to you at the river Kishon, and I will give him into your hand.'
verses.comment: The words are a direct quotation and refer to God's promise.

verses.text: Barak said to her, 'If you will go with me, I will go, but if you will not go with me, I will not go.'
verses.comment: Barak's request is rendered as directly as possible.

verses.text: And she said, 'I will surely go with you. But the honor will not be yours on the journey you are taking, for the LORD will sell Sisera into the hand of a woman.' Then Deborah arose and went with Barak to Kedesh.
verses.comment: 'Sell' means 'give over,' a word for God delivering someone into another's power.

verses.text: Barak called Zebulun and Naphtali to Kedesh, and ten thousand men went up at his feet, and Deborah went up with him.
verses.comment: 'At his feet' indicates they followed his lead.

verses.text: Now Heber the Kenite had separated from the Kenites, the descendants of Hobab, the father-in-law of Moses; he had pitched his tent as far away as the oak at Zaanannim, which is near Kedesh.
verses.comment: Clarifies Heber's relation to Moses as in Hebrew.

verses.text: When Sisera was told that Barak the son of Abinoam had gone up to Mount Tabor,
verses.comment: A fragment in Hebrew, completed in the next verse.

verses.text: Sisera called together all his chariots, nine hundred iron chariots, and all the men who were with him, from Harosheth-haggoyim to the river Kishon.
verses.comment: The numbers and locations are given as in the Hebrew text.

verses.text: And Deborah said to Barak, 'Up! For this is the day the LORD has given Sisera into your hand. Has not the LORD gone out before you?' So Barak went down from Mount Tabor with ten thousand men after him.
verses.comment: 'Up!' is the Hebrew term for 'arise.'

verses.text: The LORD routed Sisera and all his chariots and all his army before Barak by the edge of the sword, and Sisera got down from his chariot and fled away on foot.
verses.comment: 'By the edge of the sword' is a literal Hebrew phrase.

verses.text: Barak pursued the chariots and the army to Harosheth-haggoyim. All the army of Sisera fell by the edge of the sword; not even one was left.
verses.comment: 'Not even one' translates 'there was not one left.'

verses.text: But Sisera fled away on foot to the tent of Jael, the wife of Heber the Kenite, for there was peace between Jabin the king of Hazor and the house of Heber the Kenite.
verses.comment: Included 'fled away' for the repeated verb.

verses.text: Jael went out to meet Sisera and said to him, 'Turn aside, my lord, turn aside to me; do not be afraid.' So he turned aside to her into the tent, and she covered him with a rug.
verses.comment: 'Rug' can also be translated 'blanket' or 'covering.'

verses.text: He said to her, 'Please give me a little water to drink, for I am thirsty.' So she opened a skin of milk and gave him a drink and covered him.
verses.comment: The milk is an extra detail that is referenced in the song in Judges 5.

verses.text: And he said to her, 'Stand at the entrance of the tent, and if anyone comes and asks you, “Is there a man here?” say, “No.”'
verses.comment: Direct speech kept as simple as possible.

verses.text: But Jael, the wife of Heber, took a tent peg and a hammer in her hand. She went softly to him and drove the peg into his temple until it went down into the ground while he was fast asleep from weariness. So he died.
verses.comment: 'Drove' translates the Hebrew for 'struck strongly.'

verses.text: And behold, as Barak pursued Sisera, Jael went out to meet him and said to him, 'Come, and I will show you the man whom you seek.' So he went in to her, and there lay Sisera dead, with the tent peg in his temple.
verses.comment: Kept the phrase order similar to Hebrew for accuracy.

verses.text: So on that day God subdued Jabin the king of Canaan before the children of Israel.
verses.comment: 'Subdued' is a strong word meaning 'humbled' or 'brought low.'

verses.text: And the hand of the children of Israel pressed harder and harder against Jabin the king of Canaan, until they destroyed Jabin king of Canaan.
verses.comment: Conveys the sense that Israel continued to gain strength until Jabin was fully defeated.
